NoteLiteral.En:
Entry requirements: 
•	Student at any of the universities of the ECIU;
•	B2 level of English language proficiency.
Applicants need to attach a copy of ID card / passport (document issued by the country of origin) to enrol in the KTU virtual learning environment. This does not apply to KTU students (if you are a KTU student, you may attach a blank page).
Students, who are admitted and accepted the offered place in the micro-module, will be informed by email on the steps to take in order to gain access to the KTU virtual learning environment. Students will receive an email from the teacher of the micro-module on the first day of the start of module.
Students who have dropped out from the KTU micro-module(s) in the autumn 2024 are not eligible to enrol in the KTU micro-module(s) in the spring 2025.

Description.En:
Modern societies are striving for a smarter, more connected, and more sustainable future. This is the main incentive for the development of new technologies and production principles.

Therefore, it is time to rethink manufacturing. This is necessary not only to survive the "turbulent times", but also to maintain and improve the competitiveness of companies and their ability to meet the needs of society and consumers.

In this module you will learn about smart digital manufacturing, innovation processes, advanced production and organisation methods, sustainable manufacturing principles and the challenges of manufacturing transformation. You will be able to recognize the need for technological transformation, evaluate the potential of technologies, and create both technological and non-technological innovations aimed at fostering human-centred, resilient, and sustainable manufacturing. You will develop your skills thru a case study, where you will have to analyse and choose the best solution to the problem. This will allow you to focus your analytical skills and creativity to look at the manufacturing industry from a new, sustainable perspective. The knowledge and skills gained in this course will help you to propose solution for development of sustainable and digital manufacturing, transformation of manufacturing. The module consists of 6 topics and we will discuss Rethinking Manufacturing: challenges and opportunities; Supply Chain Transformation; Developing Multifunctional Digital Manufacturing; Sustainability in Industry 5.0 and Connecting Manufacturing to Customer Experience.

Title.En: Ability to recognise the need for technological transformation

NoteLiteral.En: Students will be able to recognise the need for technological transformation.

Title.En: Ability to assess the potential of digital technologies

PrefLabel.En: evaluate data, information and digital content

NoteLiteral.En: Students will be able to assess the potential of digital technologies.

Title.En: Ablity to propose technological and non-technological innovations

NoteLiteral.En: Students will be able to propose technological and non-technological innovations for a human-centred, resilient and sustainable manufacturing industry.

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
Each week you will have access to several video lectures, which usually consist of 1-4 videos, each lasting 5-15 minutes. These videos will explain the underlying theory and provide instructions for hands-on exercises that illustrate real-world scenarios. Each week includes reading material, mostly research papers, reports and websites with relevant information. Each topic is connected with individual tasks. You will have to submit a written report for each task (2 reports per 3 week, 6 reports totally).

You will have the final exam at the end of micromodule (week 4).

To pass the micromodule, you must achieve a score of 50% or higher for each graded activity. The highest possible grade is 100%. When you complete all the required micromodule activities, you will earn a final grade. The following activities are weighted out of 100% of the micromodule: 60 % reports, 10% learner’s activity, 30 % final exam.

For inquiries related to the micromodule content, please consult the Q&A section at the end of each weekly tile or click on 'Discussion Forums' in the right menu of the Moodle course. Our teachers are committed to addressing your questions promptly. In the Q&A forums, we encourage learners to engage respectfully and constructively, ensuring clarity and conciseness in queries while avoiding redundancy. Promote a collaborative environment by sharing insights and supporting peers, as courteous communication contributes to an enriched learning experience for all participants.

The micro-module will be delivered in the KTU virtual learning environment. When a student is enrolled in KTU, s/he will be informed by email on how to gain access to the micro-module.

After the successful completion of the micro-module:

- In two weeks, a student will receive an email with the link to download the ECIU University micro-credential.
- In mid-June 2025, a student from other university than KTU will receive an email with the KTU Transcript of Records that might be presented for recognition of learning outcomes at the home university.

**[Syllabus of the micromodule](https://uais.cr.ktu.lt/ktuis/stp_report_ects.mdl_ml?p_kodas=MM00M110&p_year=2024&p_lang=EN&p_stp_id=)**

Rethinking manufacturing explores the modern production where digitisation, technology, organisations and leadership intersect. Industry is going through an era of productivity transformation, where machines and people are working together to redefine how work gets done.  

This micromodule is designed for undergraduate students in different fields of engineering and technologies who want to change manufacturing and create a better world. 

The aim of the micromodule is to develop global and critical awareness of smart digital manufacturing, innovation processes, intelligent production and organisation methods, sustainable manufacturing principles, and challenges of manufacturing transformation.

Entry requirements:

- Student at any of the universities of the ECIU;
- B2 level of English language proficiency.

Applicants need to attach a copy of ID card / passport (document issued by the country of origin) to enrol in the KTU virtual learning environment. This does not apply to KTU students (if you are a KTU student, you may attach a blank page).

Students, who are admitted and accepted the offered place in the micro-module, will be informed by email on the steps to take in order to gain access to the KTU virtual learning environment. Students will receive an email from the teacher of the micro-module on the first day of the start of module.

Students who have dropped out from the KTU micro-module(s) in the autumn 2024 are not eligible to enrol in the KTU micro-module(s) in the spring 2025.
